In a few sentences, please explain the reasons why you trust or distrust your primary care physician. If you do not have a primary care physician, please answer in regard to doctors in general.

I don't necessarily trust doctors. Some are very trustworthy, others are not trustworthy at all. Doctors are often more caught up in imposing their ideas on their patients and don't actually listen to their patients. Too often they tell women that losing weight will fix all their problems or that they can't have a hysterectomy, even when it is medically called for, because they might want to have children later. Too many of them have relationships with drug companies that make it hard for them to be fair-minded about which treatments are best. Some of them haven't kept up with the latest in medical science news.

In a few sentences, please explain the reasons why you trust or distrust your primary care physician. If you do not have a primary care physician, please answer in regard to doctors in general.

My primary care physician takes great care of me. She is attentive and remembers details and LISTENS to me. I have seen many other doctors whether walk-in or specialists who do not listen to what I say. If they do not listen to me, they can't possibly diagnose me correctly. If a doctor is dismissive or rude, I won't trust a word out of their mouth.I find a new doctor as soon as possible. Last year, I had a piece of my jaw come loose and fall out of my mouth (it was as horrible as it sounds), in the beginning it just hurt a lot, and I could see my bone through my gums. The male doctor I saw at the walk-in told me there was no way it was my jaw and I probably had a cankersore. I asked him to look and he glanced into my mouth without a flashlight. Yeah, I spat out a piece of my jaw a few weeks later after several appointments with an oral surgeon.
In a few sentences, please describe what makes you feel most anxious or worried when visiting the doctor's office.

I am often worried about whether I will be treated with respect, more than anything. Or that the doctor I see will dismiss whatever I am struggling with. I also struggle a little with blood draws-- I get incredibly faint. Sometimes I am nervous for my own health, but most of the time if I'm not seeing my primary care doctor, I'm just rolling the dice as to whether I'll get someone rude and disinterested or someone who's an actual professional.
In a few sentences, please describe an experience in your life that demonstrated your knowledge of health or medical issues.

Many years ago I noticed something was wrong with my husband and sent him to the doctor multiple times. Every time they sent him back and said he was fine. Until years later, he saw another doctor who immediately sent him for an ultrasound. He had testicular cancer and had a tumor growing for the past several years. All I knew is if they couldn't tell me what it is, they couldn't tell me what it wasn't-- they had to check.

In a few sentences, please describe what makes you feel most anxious or worried when visiting the doctor's office.

The doctor herself doesn't make me feel uncomfortable or nervous, it is the consequences related to my problems that make we worried.

I did some research online to see what other things could be causing my pain. One of them was ovarian cysts. I went to a gynecologist and she confirmed that I had cysts.
